Award.AwardTitle: HBCU-UP Targeted Infusion: Interdisciplinary Bioenergy Undergraduate Research and Instruction program at FVSU

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Education and Human Resources

Award.AbstractNarration:
Fort Valley State University (FVSU) will address the undersupply of professionals trained in renewable energy and efficiency through the National Science Foundation's Historically Black Colleges and Universities (HBCU-UP) Undergraduate Program's 36-month Targeted Infusion Project. FVSU, a Historically Black College/University (HBCU), through this project will address regional and global issues in the biofuel industry through its curriculum development and revision to incorporate multidisciplinary courses in bioenergy, e. g., policy development, biotechnology, bioeconomy, fuel conversion in providing students and faculty cutting edge research opportunities and science, technology, engineering and mathematics (STEM) professional development.

Over 100 students will participate in the research and educational courses during the three-year duration of the project. Collaborations with Iowa State University's Department of Biosystems Engineering, the Donald Danforth Plant Science Center, Delaware State University?s Center for Integrated Biological and Environmental Research and the South Dakota State University College of Agriculture and Biological Sciences, among other prominent research institutions, provides broad opportunities for this minority-serving institution (MSI) to offer cutting-edge research opportunities to project participants. The impact from the project's implementation uniquely addresses the regional needs contributing to the enhancement of rural economic development and green industry in the South and the nation in addition to contributing to a diverse STEM workforce in the bioenergy sciences.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Fort Valley State University (FVSU) is an 1890 Land Grant institution serving a student population of 2,700 (93% African Americans). Student-focused project activities have been designed to enhance student retention and persistence from the first year of college to graduation in Biotechnology and Engineering Technology (BETech). The overall goal is to recruit, enroll, and retain through expanding articulation agreements between eight neighboring two year technical and State Colleges and FVSU and three military bases. The project will also prepare future leaders in governmental, academia, and private industries those have solid basic training and applied skills in critical STEM areas with an emphasis on biotechnology and engineering technology.

Intellectual Merit:

The measurable objectives are:  1) Expand pathways to FVSU STEM and technology education to include articulation agreements between nearby two year Technical and State Colleges and recruit under-represented minorities, veterans or those in the National Guard, Hispanic and non-traditional mature minority students with interest in STEM disciplines;  2) Undertake recruitment activities for undergraduates who have an Associate Degree or students enrolled in the dual enrollment program and have earned 30-36 hours of college credit 3) strengthening the academic, peer and advising support system, undergraduate experiential learning, internships and cooperative education and to develop discipline-specific related extra-curricular activities designed to generate and sustain the student interest in STEM education;  4) Undertake curriculum revision to increase the  retention rate of students in STEM courses, individualize tutoring and peer mentoring programs, develop closed loop assessment and midstream intervention mechanisms; and 5) Support faculty development to ensure technical currency and continuous quality improvement among program faculty.

Overall the proposed program activities are designed to accommodate the needs of three culturally and demographically different pools of eligible participants, with the common goal of success. The proposed program is designed based on the existing strengths of the institution, established partnerships, and critical review and needs assessment by an experienced group of STEM faculty, the principal investigator, external evaluator, and advisory boards (internal/external). The program will create support for strong student engagement through collaborative learning and research, and campus research mentorship supplemented by summer internships. The Leadership Team (PI, distinguished faculty members from STEM departments, an Advisory Committees consisting of internal and external evaluation teams for formative evaluation. The project outcomes will be disseminated widely among other minority-serving institutions and in the professional community through presentations at regional and national/scientific meetings. The mid-Georgia community will have access to the successful efforts of this project through FVSU web site. The commitment of institution is evidenced from the FVSU President, allocation of physical facilities for the teaching and research laboratories and use of other facilities and resources.

 

Broader Impacts: Our program will capitalize on innovative approaches designed to develop a highly qualified STEM workforce. Increasing the number of under-represented minorities, veterans or those in the National Guard, Hispanic and non-traditional mature minority students receiving B.S. degrees in STEM disciplines will enhance the workforce for Georgia and the nation. The growth will positively impact the diversity essential for leadership in academia and incorporate research venues. The Model strategies will be tested, refined, and disseminated for broader impact, regionally and nationally, and for success of similar programs other institutions. This program has already served as a recruitment and retention tool for the institution and enabled FVSU to gain visibility as a student-centered institution that provides opportunities for student research at undergraduate level. Further, this project will develop a model for interdisciplinary collaborations in research and curriculum particularly suitable for small teaching institutions.
